posts.post_content:
I can't adequately state how much I love this card.   
  
Mtg has always been about how your deck works as a whole. I love how this card has so much potential, depending on what deck you throw him in and can become so devastating in so many different ways. I hope this is a *precursor* to more cards with a wide number of uses depending on how you build a deck with them.  
  
I can think of different ways to use him for every color and most color combos, and can't wait to using this guy in a number of different ways.

I hope this is a precursor to more cards with a wide number of uses depending on how you build a deck with them.

I can think of different ways to use him for every color and most color combos, and can't wait to using this guy in a number of different ways.

posts.post_content:
Look, you NEED to do math with this guy. [Rite of Replication](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rite of Replication) is likely the best way to go, and you should always target one of the TOKENS with it. Watch.  
  
1 Precursor, 2 Tokens. Targetting the token with a kicked Rite gives this:  
6 Precursors, 12 Tokens (and 10 more tokens from the new Precursors). This is the 28 people mention. Let's go further with another kicked Rite on the Token:  
6 Precursors, each copied into 5, and each has 6 instances of "copied" on them. This means that the total number of Precursors GAINED is 180, or (6^2)(5). Then, you add the original 6 to there, and you have 186 Precursors. I'm ignoring the Token count at this point. Just assume that it's already massive. A third kicked Rite:  
(186^2)(5) + 186 = new Precursor count. This is equal to no less than 173166 Precursors. Fourth kicked Rite:  
149,932,490,946 Precursor Golem cards on your field total. NOW you cast a single instance of [Distortion Strike](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Distortion Strike). This is the equivalent ... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

posts.post_content:
Argh, I've had such mixed luck with this card. Seems like half the games I run my opponent over with nine power, and half the games something... unpleasant happens.   
  
Once I had it [Slice In Twain](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Slice In Twain)'d; lost that game pretty badly. Another time it fell to [Flesh Allergy](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Flesh Allergy); losing 6 life in addition to my golems wasn't particularly fun. My worst experience was in a cube draft, where my opponent kicked [Into the Roil](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Into the Roil) on it. I cast it again, and he stole all my golems with [Ray of Command](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ray of Command) and beat me to death.  
  
This guy is pretty much the definition of "high risk, high reward". Plenty of good combos for you--watch for the ones that go badly.
posts.html:

My worst experience was in a cube draft, where my opponent kicked Into the Roil on it. I cast it again, and he stole all my golems with Ray of Command and beat me to death.

This guy is pretty much the definition of "high risk, high reward". Plenty of good combos for you--watch for the ones that go badly.

posts.post_content:
@LPFan55 When using [Flesh Allergy](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Flesh Allergy), the opponent wouldn't lose 12 life. The opponent would lose life equal all creatures put into the graveyard this turn (prior to Flesh Allergy resolving from the stack). In other words if the opponent lost 3 life because of flesh allergy, the opponent would not lose any more life from that same instance of flesh allergy even if more creatures went to the graveyard after the original Flesh allergy resolved.   
  
To calculate: There are 2 golems and one [Precursor Golem](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Precursor Golem) on opponents battlefield. You have 1 creature. You cast [Flesh Allergy](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Flesh Allergy), sacrifice your creature and target one of the golems. This is the original spell and is put on the bottom of the stack. Two more copies of the spell are then put on the stack in the order of your choice, each targeting a different golem. So the last target you pick would resolve first. At this point in the stack only 2 creatures have gone to the graveyard (the ... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

posts.post_content:
You guys are all being so restrained with this guy's potential.  
  
Start off with 4 [Parallel Lives](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Parallel Lives) and 4 [Doubling Season](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Doubling Season). Then play 4 Precursor Golems. The Enchantments multiply the tokens by 256, so you have 4 Precursor Golems and 2048 3/3 Golems.  
  
(You all know the general craziness of how this will play out, so I'll spare you most of the mathematical waffle.)  
  
Then, play a [Cytoshape](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Cytoshape), making all of your golems into Precursor Golems. Then play and Flashback 4 [Cackling Counterpart](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Cackling Counterpart)s. You now have 10^1458 Precursor Golems, and 10^1461 3/3 Golems.  
  
Then drop a 3 copies of [Rite of Replication](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rite of Replication), all kicked. Maths happens, and you end up with 10^11727 Precursor Golems, and 10^11730 3/3 Golem tokens.  
  
Then play your fourth kicked Rite of Replication, but we'll copy it with an [Increasing Vengeance](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Increasing Vengeance) or 4. Then we'll start chaining 4 flashbacked Increasing Vengeances, flash i... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

(You all know the general craziness of how this will play out, so I'll spare you most of the mathematical waffle.)

Then, play a Cytoshape, making all of your golems into Precursor Golems. Then play and Flashback 4 Cackling Counterparts. You now have 10^1458 Precursor Golems, and 10^1461 3/3 Golems.

Then drop a 3 copies of Rite of Replication, all kicked. Maths happens, and you end up with 10^11727 Precursor Golems, and 10^11730 3/3 Golem tokens.

Then play your fourth kicked Rite of Replication, but we'll copy it with an Increasing Vengeance or 4. Then we'll start chaining 4 flashbacked Increasing Vengeances, flash i... (see all)

posts.post_content: Ugh....you guys.....he's not card disadvantage if they shoot him down. It's a 1-for-1. HE makes the tokens, so if they Doom Blade him, you lose 1 card and they lose 1 card. Not a 3-for-1. He's a very solid card which can end games quickly and is pretty potent when paired with stuff like Vines of Vastwood, Withstand Death, or even Asceticism.

posts.post_content:
Any cantrip that targets it gives you three cards.  
  
Tainted Strike allows it to end the game in one fell swoop.  
  
This creature is a huge risk, but it could be very well broken with the right deck.  
  
ALSO: Searing blaze doesn't triple itself, since doesn't just target one golem.

posts.post_content:
@XaiviarNightwing: [Rite of Replication](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rite of Replication) and [Radiate](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Radiate):  
  
1. Cast kicked Rite.  
2. Precursor Golem makes two other copies of Rite on the stack.  
3. Radiate the spell targeting a token, which adds a copy for the Precursor and a copy for the other token to the stack.  
4. Two kicked Rites on the Precursor make 10 Precursor tokens, which make 20 vanilla tokens as they enter.  
5. Three kicked RItes on the other two tokens make 15 more vanilla tokens.  
6. Wait for the dust to settle.  
7. You own 11 Precursor Golems (10 are token copies) and 37 3/3 golems.  
8. Cast [Traitorous Instinct](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Traitorous Instinct) on any golem. That golem gets +2/+0 and haste, every other golem gets +22/+0 and haste.  
10. ATTACK FOR 1180! Only cost ![13](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=13&type=symbol)![Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=U&type=symbol)![Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=U&type=symbol)![Red](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=R&type=symbol)![Red](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=R&type=symbol)![Red](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=R&type=symbol).

posts.post_content:
So here's what you do with this guy -  
  
Play Precursor Golem, and enchant him with [Indestructibility](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Indestructibility), then play [Xenograft](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Xenograft) naming Golem and [Donate](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Donate) it to your opponent. Lastly, [Murder](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Murder) one of their creatures, or your own Precursor, or one of its tokens - really, any golem. BAM! Needlessly complex one-sided board wipe that is, conveniently, repeatable and in Esper colours. For extra stupidity, imprint [Doom Blade](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Doom Blade) on [Isochron Scepter](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Isochron Scepter). Two mana to wipe his board of all non-black creatures at will - though since you're going that route and not paying the cost anyway, why not use [Terminate](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Terminate) instead? Or, since we're really going needlessly complex, get two of the scepter, one imprinted with either [Pongify](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Pongify) or [Rapid Hybridization](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rapid Hybridization) and the other imprinted with [Smother](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Smother). Zap all their creatures in... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
